awd_abstract_narration:
This study will investigate a novel RNA-based mechanism that allows plants to respond to stress that affects the DNA, and to transmit a signal that protects chromosome integrity, which is important for plant fertility, growth and disease prevention. This project  will develop fundamental knowledge valuable for breeding and growing healthier plants.  This project will integrate basic plant science research with the teaching and training of the next-generation of plant scientists.  As part of this effort, laboratory management workshops for postdoctoral fellows and new faculty will be conducted, and a graduate course on this topic will be developed.

The overarching goal of this project is to elucidate the molecular mechanism and regulation of TER2, a novel telomerase-associated long noncoding RNA (lncRNA) from the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. TER2 is a negative regulator of telomerase that is rapidly stabilized in response to DNA double-strand breaks. Induction of TER2 represses telomerase activity and is hypothesized to promote faithful repair of DNA damage. TER2 is also necessary for reproductive fitness through an unknown mechanism. A combination of biochemical, genetic, cell biological and computational strategies will be used to study TER2.  Objective 1 will define key structural elements that regulate TER2 processing/metabolism for the purpose of identifying the DNA damage sensor within TER2 and the elements that control TER2 stability.  Objective 2 will investigate the role of small RNA processing machinery in promoting TER2 turnover by testing if TER2 is a substrate for cleavage by Dicer 2. Objective 3 will examine the contribution of TER2 in Arabidopsis reproduction by testing whether the fertility-related defects in ter2 mutants reflect aberrant male gametogenesis or the effect of a paternally expressed imprinted gene.  Altogether, the results of this work will establish new paradigms for lncRNA regulation and increase understanding of RNA-based pathways that promote genome stability.

Intellectual merit:

Telomeres are the physical ends of eukaryotic chromosomes.  Telomeric DNA is maintained by the action of telomerase, a specialized reverse transcriptase containing a catalytic subunit (TERT) and a long noncoding RNA (TER or TR) which serves as a template to direct synthesis of telomeric DNA repeats. Telomerase activity is essential for genome stability and cell proliferation. Consequently, mammalian telomerase has been extensively studied due to its association with cancer. In contrast, little is known about the composition and regulation of telomerase in plants. The telomerase RNA subunit is particularly enigmatic as it is highly divergent in sequence and structure. This has confounded efforts to identify telomerase RNA from evolutionarily divergent species.

The premise of this project was based on the association of two long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) with Arabidopsis thaliana telomerase, the conventional telomerase RNA subunit, AtTER1, and a non-canonical regulatory RNA, AtTER2 (Cifuentes-Rojas et al., 2011). However, during the course of this project, research in our lab and in others called this premise into question. Using an unbiased approach to identify additional lncRNAs that associate with AtTERT, we failed to find either AtTER1 or AtTER2 (Fajkus et al., 2019; Song et al., 2019; Dew-Budd et al., 2020). The mistaken identification of AtTER1 was likely due to bias in the original telomerase purification strategy, incorrect assumptions about the predicted RNA template and PCR artifacts. We corrected the literature by retracting the original PNAS paper reporting AtTER1. This unexpected finding sent us back to the bench to find the true telomerase RNA subunit for Arabidopsis. Our search was successful (Song et al., 2019). After partial purification of A. thaliana telomerase followed by next-generation sequencing of RNAs that co-purified with AtTERT, a single RNA, AtTR, was highly enriched. Genetic analysis demonstrated AtTR was essential for telomere maintenance in vivo and telomerase activity in vitro. In collaboration with Julian Chen’s lab (Arizona State University), we developed and biochemically tested a secondary structure model for AtTR, which was subsequently verified in vivo using genetic complementation experiments with transgenic plants expressing targeted TR mutations. Our model for plant TR unexpectedly revealed features of both vertebrate and ciliate TR molecules, as well as additional structural elements unique to plants. Thus, plant TR is an important evolutionary bridge that unites the disparate structures of the previously characterized TR molecules.  

We also re-examined the AtTER2 locus. Updated genome annotation for A. thaliana revealed that TER2 completely overlapped the tRNA Adenosine Deaminase 3 (TAD3) gene. Using a variety of biochemical and bioinformatics approaches, we found that TAD3 does not encode a stable lncRNA. Interestingly, however, TAD3 is required for telomere length maintenance; telomeres shorten progressively in tad3 mutants. This telomere maintenance defect does not reflect compromised chromosome end protection. Instead, TAD3 promotes telomere maintenance via a non-canonical, telomerase-independent pathway. Transcriptomics of tad3 mutants showed dysregulation of genes involved in auxin signaling, secondary metabolite pathways and cell cycle, arguing that TAD3 plays an indirect role in telomere length homeostasis by regulating the metabolic profile of Arabidopsis (Bose et al. 2020). 

 

Scientific Impacts: 

Our discovery of the bona-fide TR from A. thaliana is a significant breakthrough for the field and opens new horizons for understanding telomerase structure and evolution in the plant kingdom. In addition, the discovery of TAD3 as a novel regulatory of telomere length underscores the wide network of environmental, developmental and metabolic factors that influence telomere biology in plants.

 

Broader Impacts:

This grant funded the research of 3 postdoctoral fellows, 3 PhD students, 1 Master’s student, numerous graduate rotation students and 4 undergraduate students. In addition, with support from this grant, my students and postdocs presented the results of their research at multiple scientific conferences and published five peer-reviewed papers.
